description: From Middle French pause, from Latin pausa, from Ancient Greek παῦσις (paûsis), from Ancient Greek παύω (paúō, “stop”), of uncertain origin. Compare the doublet pausa.

entries.meaning: A temporary stop or rest; an intermission of action; interruption; suspension; cessation.
examples: Synonyms: hiatus, moratorium, recess; see also Thesaurus:pause

entries.meaning: A short time for relaxing and doing something else.
examples: Synonyms: break, holiday, recess; see also Thesaurus:vacation

entries.meaning: In writing and printing, a mark indicating the place and nature of an arrest of voice in reading; a punctuation mark.
examples: Teach the pupil to mind the pauses.

entries.meaning: A break or paragraph in writing.
(music) A sign indicating continuance of a note or rest.
Alternative spelling of Pause (“a button that pauses or resumes something”)
(as direct object) take pause: hesitate; give pause: cause to hesitate

verbs.description: pause (third-person singular simple present pauses, present participle pausing, simple past and past participle paused)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To take a temporary rest, take a break for a short period after an effort.
(intransitive) To interrupt an activity and wait.
examples: When telling the scary story, he paused for effect.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To hesitate; to hold back; to delay.
(transitive) To halt the play or playback of, temporarily, so that it can be resumed from the same point.
examples: to pause a song, a video, or a computer game
